text.section:
In Harford County, subject to the provisions of subsections (c) and (d) of this section, the Liquor Control Board may issue:
A CWBT license to holders of a Class A1 BWL license; and
A WBT license to holders of a Class A BW license.

section.section: The CWBT license permits the on-premises consumption of cordials, wine, beer, and liquor for tasting or sampling purposes only.
The WBT license permits the on-premises consumption of wine and beer for tasting or sampling purposes only.

The holder of a Class A1 BWL license may apply for and the Liquor Control Board may issue a CWBT license that is effective for a maximum of:
Any 26 days in a licensing period;
Any 52 days in a licensing period; or
365 days in a licensing period.

The fees for a CWBT license under this subsection are:
For a license that is effective for any 26 days in a licensing period, $125;
For a license that is effective for any 52 days in a licensing period, $200; and
For a license that is effective for 365 days in a licensing period, $400.

The holder of a Class A BW license may apply for and the Liquor Control Board may issue a WBT license that is effective for a maximum of:
Any 26 days in a licensing period;
Any 52 days in a licensing period; or
365 days in a licensing period.

The fees for a WBT license under this subsection are:
For a license that is effective for any 26 days in a licensing period, $100;
For a license that is effective for any 52 days in a licensing period, $150; and
For a license that is effective for 365 days in a licensing period, $225.

text.section: A licensee that is issued a CWBT or a WBT license under this section for any 26 days in a licensing period or any 52 days in a licensing period shall notify the Liquor Control Board at least 7 days prior to exercising the provisions of the tasting or sampling license, of the licensee's intent to have a tasting or sampling.

Tasting and sampling servings per person are limited to:
1 ounce of each given brand of beer or wine;
One-half ounce of each given brand of cordial; and
One-half ounce of each brand of any other alcoholic beverage.
The Liquor Control Board may adopt regulations providing additional requirements to implement this subsection.
